case_name: Dr. S. P. Mukerjee, Shri N. C. Chatterjee, Pandit Nandial Sharma and Pandit Guru Dutt Vaid v. Union of India

facts.text: Petition No. 54 of 1953 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 54 of 1953. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petition filed by Jai Gopal Sethi on behalf of Ham Narayan Singh for Dr. S. P. Mukerjee, Shri N. C. Chatterjee, Pandit Nandial Sharma and Pandit Guru Dutt Vaid.

anchor.surface_text: Jai Gopal Sethi and Veda Vyas  S. K. Kapur, A. K. Datt, N. Chona, B. Pathnaik and A. AT. Sinha, with them  for the petitioners. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General for India  Porus Mehta, with him  for the respondents. 1953. March 12.

facts.text: Four persons arrested on the evening of 6th March 1953.

anchor.surface_text: PATANJALI SASTRI C. J.-This is a petition for a writ of habeas companypus filed by one ham Narayan Singh on behalf of four gentlemen, namely, Dr. S. P. Mukerjee, Shri N. C. Chatterjee, Pandit Nandial Sharma and Pandit Guru Dutt Vaid, who are the real petitioners in the case. These persons were arrested on the evening of the 6th March, 1953,

facts.text: Arrested persons prosecuted for alleged defiance of order prohibiting meetings and processions under section 188 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: and they are number being prosecuted for alleged defiance of an order prohibiting meetings and processions in the area in question, an offence punishable under section 188 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Detention justified by remand order passed by Mr. Dhillon, Additional District Magistrate, Delhi, at about 8 p.m. on 6th March 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Their detention is sought to be justified on the basis of two remand orders, the one alleged to have been- passed by Mr. Dhillon, Additional District Magistrate, Delhi, at about 8 p. m. on the 6th March, 1953,

facts.text: Second remand order alleged passed by trying Magistrate at about 3 p.m. on 9th March 1953 while adjourning the case.

anchor.surface_text: and the other alleged to have been passed by the trying Magistrate at about 3 p. m. on the 9th March while adjourning the case on the representation made before him that a habeas pus petition was being moved in this Court.

facts.text: First remand order dated 6th March expired on 9th March and is no longer in force.

anchor.surface_text: but we companysider it unnecessary to enter upon a discussion of those questions, as it is number companyceded that the first order of remand dated the 6th March even assuming it was a valid one expired on the 9th March and is numberlonger in force.

facts.text: Trying Magistrate proceeded under section 344 CrPC for adjournment and remand.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the order of remand alleged to have been made by the trying Magistrate on the 9th March, the position is as follows-The trying Magistrate was obviously proceeding at that stage under section 344 of the Criminal Procedure Code, which requires him, if he chooses to adjourn the case pending before him, to remand by warrant the accused if in custody,

facts.text: Order under s.344 CrPC must be in writing signed by presiding Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: and it goes on to provide Every order made under this section by a companyrt other than a High Court shall be in writing signed by the presiding Judge or Magistrate.

facts.text: Court ordered production of records on 10th March 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Magistrate under this section was produced before us in companypliance with an order of this Court made on the 10th March, which directed the production in this Court as early as possible of the records before the Additional District Magistrate and the trying Magistrate together with the remand papers for inspection by Counsel for the petitioner.

facts.text: Produced order of trying Magistrate only directs adjournment to 11th March, no remand direction.

anchor.surface_text: The order produced merely directs the adjournment of the case till the 11th March and companytains numberdirection for, remanding the accused to custody till that date.

facts.text: Four slips of paper handed to Registrar at 5:20 p.m. last evening, purporting to be warrants dated 6th March 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Last evening, four slips of paper were handed to the Registrar of this Court at 5-20 p. m. On one side they purport to be warrants of detention dated 6th March and addressed to the Superintendent of Jail, Delhi, directing the accused to be kept in judicial lock-up and to be produced in companyrt on the 9th March 1953.

facts.text: Slips contain endorsements on back: Remanded to judicial till 11th March 1953.

anchor.surface_text: These warrants companytain on their back the following endorsements Remanded to judicial till 11th March, 1953

facts.text: Slips not produced despite court order of 10th March.

anchor.surface_text: In a question of habeas companypus, when the lawfulness or otherwise of the custody of the persons companycerned is in question, it is obvious that these documents, if genuine would be of vital importance, but they were number produced, numberwithstanding the clear direction companytained in our order of the 10th March.

facts.text: Court records do not contain any order of remand on 9th March.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt records produced before us do number companytain any order of remand made on the 9th March. As we have already observed, we have the order of the trying Magistrate merely adjourning the case to the 11th.

facts.text: Solicitor-General explained slips were with police officer present in court yesterday, filed at 5:20 p.m. after court rose.

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor-General appearing on behalf of the Government explains that these slips of paper,which would be of crucial importance to the case, were with a police officer who was present in companyrt yesterday, but after the Court rose in the evening the latter thought that their production might be of some importance and therefore they were filed before the Registrar at 5-20 p. m.

facts.text: Court does not take notice of documents produced in such circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot take numberice of documents produced in such circumstances, and we are number satisfied that there was any order of remand companymitting the accused to further custody till the 11th March.

facts.text: No order of remand committing accused to custody till 11th March.

anchor.surface_text: we are number satisfied that there was any order of remand companymitting the accused to further custody till the 11th March.

facts.text: In habeas corpus, court regards legality of detention at time of return, not institution.

anchor.surface_text: It has been held by this Court that in habeas companypus proceedings, the Court is to have regard to the legality or otherwise of the detention at the time of the return and number with reference to the institution of the proceedings.

facts.text: Material date is 10th March 1953, when affidavit filed justifying detention.

anchor.surface_text: The material date on the facts of this case is the 10th March, when the affidavit on behalf of the Government was filed justifying the detention as a lawful one.

facts.text: On 10th March 1953, there was no order remanding the four persons to custody.

anchor.surface_text: But the position, as we have stated, is that on that date there was numberorder remanding the four persons to custody.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 12, 1953 by Chief Justice Patanjali Sastri.

issues.text: Whether the order of remand alleged to have been made by the trying Magistrate on the 9th March is valid under section 344 of the Criminal Procedure Code

anchor.surface_text: under section 344 of the Criminal Procedure Code, which requires him, if he chooses to adjourn the case pending before him, to remand by warrant the accused if in custody, and it goes on to provide Every order made under this section by a companyrt other than a High Court shall be in writing signed by the presiding Judge or Magistrate; absence of such signed written order invalidates remand

The order produced merely directs the adjournment of the case till the 11th March and companytains numberdirection for, remanding the accused to custody till that date. It has been held by this Court that in habeas companypus proceedings, the Court is to have regard to the legality or otherwise of the detention at the time of the return and number with reference to the institution of the proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: It has been held by this Court that in habeas companypus proceedings, the Court is to have regard to the legality or otherwise of the detention at the time of the return and number with reference to the institution of the proceedings. The material date on the facts of this case is the 10th March, when the affidavit on behalf of the Government was filed justifying the detention as a lawful one. But the position, as we have stated, is that on that date there was numberorder remanding the four persons to custody.
